subproject.corporate outcome: Development plans and programmes integrate environmentally sustainable solutions in a manner that promotes poverty reduction, MDG achievement and low-emission climate-resilient development
subproject.description: EEG’s global mainstreaming “vision” is to be organised in integrated teams and speak with one voice to provide world class expertise and assistance to COs. In this capacity, EEG contributes to UNDP alignment of global, regional, and national agendas in its service to countries. Working in aligned and integrated teams, EEG supports COs to incorporate environment and energy into UNDP programming (i.e. UN Development Assistance Frameworks and Country Programmes).  Through UNDP programming, COs in turn help countries integrate environmental sustainability into their development planning and implementation by means of poverty reduction, national development, and sectoral development instruments, supported by global programmes such as the Poverty Environment Initiative (PEI).
subproject.title: Environmental Mainstreaming

subproject.corporate outcome: Development plans and programmes integrate environmentally sustainable solutions in a manner that promotes poverty reduction, MDG achievement and low-emission climate-resilient development

subproject.title: Environmental Mainstreaming

subproject.corporate outcome: Local and national authorities have the capacities to access and integrate multiple sources of public and private environmental financing in support of sustainable human development, including gender equality and poverty reduction
subproject.description: Local capacities will have to be built to leverage low-income countries to benefit from new innovative instruments.  To implement market-based instruments, developing countries will need significant support to ensure that financial markets are ready. Similar  capacity development efforts will be required to identify and implement appropriate innovative investments at different levels,  including at the sub-national level.
subproject.title: Environmental Finance

subproject.corporate outcome: Local and national authorities have the capacities to access and integrate multiple sources of public and private environmental financing in support of sustainable human development, including gender equality and poverty reduction

subproject.title: Environmental Finance

subproject.corporate outcome: National and local governments and communities have the capacities to adapt to climate change and make inclusive and sustainable environment & energy decisions benefitting in particular under-served populations
subproject.description: Through the Environment and Energy Global Programme 2009-2011, UNDP will strengthen the capacity of developing countries to mainstream policies that address climate change and reflect the critical linkages to the achievement the MDGs, poverty alleviation, good govern-ance, and gender-responsiveness into their national development plans. EEG will do so by first consolidating, coordinating, and promoting UNDP’s policy positions on climate change which, in turn, will strengthen its own ability to provide support to countries. Targeted outreach materials and publications as well as projects aimed at enhancing the strategic positioning of UNDP on the linkages between development and climate change are essential. Increased support and capacity development for COs is also key to reaching the outcome. EEG will ensure UNDP’s effective participation in the UNFCCC and improve UNDP’s work with other UN bodies and intergovernmental agencies.
donor_long: UN FRAMEWORK CONVENTION ON CLIMATE CHANG
subproject.title: Climate Change

subproject.corporate outcome: National and local governments and communities have the capacities to adapt to climate change and make inclusive and sustainable environment & energy decisions benefitting in particular under-served populations
subproject.description: Environmental finance mechanisms, such as carbon finance and payments for other ecosystem services, are emerging as potentially powerful new funding sources for the environment, energy, and sustainable development. EEG is investing significantly in tapping into these new financing mechanisms and has developed a set of facilities5 such as the Energy Facility, Community-Based  Adaptation (CBA), Territorial Approach, etc. with the potential to unleash and redirect resources to the local level.  EEG is  establishing a Local Capacity Facility that will: (i) Coordinate work within EEG to ensure key international environmental financial  mechanisms benefit the local level and provide responsive, demand-driven financing and grant-making; (ii) Support national  governments to provide enabling policies and investments required for the effective implementation of EEG’s Financing Facilities at  the local level; and (iii) Support local actors to access environmental finance and deliver Facilities’ programmes at the local level.
subproject.title: Local Access

subproject.corporate outcome: National and local governments and communities have the capacities to adapt to climate change and make inclusive and sustainable environment & energy decisions benefitting in particular under-served populations

subproject.corporate outcome: National and local governments and communities have the capacities to adapt to climate change and make inclusive and sustainable environment & energy decisions benefitting in particular under-served populations
subproject.description: The Communities of Practice are central to UNDP’s approach towards knowledge sharing, innovation, collaboration, and the  provision of support to COs delivering UNDP services globally. Currently, the Environment and Energy Practice Network (EE-Net), in collaboration with global and regional advisors and external partners is directly supporting over 1000 practitioners in the field including over 300 Country Office Environment and Energy Focal Points, provides a wide range of services. These include facilitated discussions addressing specific issues related to the implementation of UNDP programmes, off-line backstopping, access to resources, and expert referrals, among others. These services and existing community of practice infrastructure will be maintained and improved until the new knowledge platform, Teamworks, is developed and rolled out, which would allow to expand the scope of the services and further integrate the community of practice concept into the UNDP business model.
subproject.title: Knowledge Management
